cluster_relations.rel_desc: General relativity is cited as an example of a gravitational theory tested using black holes.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a set, category, or collection includes a particular member or example.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Fundamental Physics Theories Tested with Black Holes

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: in contexts such as black hole tests
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ExampleRelation: general relativity is one such theory

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Gravitational waves are one of the cosmic phenomena being studied.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject entity is an instance or example of the object category or type.
remarks: Slight ambiguity whether pronoun refers only to black holes or also their gravitational waves; relation added with moderate confidence.
Slight ambiguity whether pronoun refers only to black holes or also their gravitational waves; relation added with moderate confidence.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Black holes are an example of cosmic phenomena mentioned in the text.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject entity is an instance or example of the object category or type.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Category: large-scale astrophysical objects and events

remarks: Relation used to tie black holes to the broader cosmic phenomena category.
Relation used to tie black holes to the broader cosmic phenomena category.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Quantum gravity is given as an example of the proposed new physics beyond general relativity.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is an illustrative instance or example of the broader category or idea given by the object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject category or collection has the object as a member or example instance.
args.justification: This relation links a category ('gravitational theories') to a specific example ('general relativity'), so it is the inverse of instance_of. Using 'has_member' aligns with common ontology patterns, and grouping it under 'category_membership_relation' with rel_cls_group 'IDENTITY' makes it consistent with the other instance-of/example membership edges in this cluster.

This relation encodes that 'quantum gravity' is an example of the broader category 'new physics', which is semantically a type of category membership. Aligning its rel_cls with 'category_membership_relation' and rel_cls_group with 'IDENTITY' harmonizes it with the existing 'is_instance_of' relations, which represent the same family of category/instance semantics.
